{{quote|Back to pasture, back to mead,
Where the kine and oxen feed!|''[[The Hobbit]]'', [[Barrels Out of Bond]]{{cite DTP|H 09.053}}}} [[File:The Lord of the Rings - The Fellowship of the Ring - Simple Living.jpg|thumb|250px|Cow being milked by a [[Hobbits|Hobbit]] - ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring]]'']] '''Cows''', also known by the archaic plural '''Kine''' and occasionally as '''Oxen''', were pasture animals in [[Middle-earth]]. ==History== Cows were domesticated for farm use in most of [[Middle-earth]]. They produced milk, which was used as a beverage in [[Gondor]],{{HM|RK}}, "[[The Siege of Gondor]]" and [[the Shire]].{{HM|H}}, "[[An Unexpected Party]]" Being generally stronger than [[horses]], cows also pulled the heavier wagons and wains in Middle-earth.{{HM|RK}}, "[[Minas Tirith (chapter)|Minas Tirith]]" Yet still, there were undomesticated oxen. The wild-oxen of the East were, according to legend, descended from the [[Kine of Araw]], the herd of [[Oromë]].{{HM|AA}}, "The Realms in Exile" [[Vorondil the Hunter]] hunted them in the far fields of [[Rhûn]], and of their horns he made the [[Great Horn]] of Gondor, which served as an heirloom to the House of Stewards until its destruction. ==Inspiration== Cows are a major source of food even in today's world. Their use as farm animals seems little more than logical. [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] spent most of his life in [[Oxford|'''Ox'''ford]], and cows would also play a role in other stories, such as ''[[Farmer Giles of Ham]]'', where [[the Giant]] steps on [[Farmer Giles]]' favourite cow, [[Galathea]].[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[Tales from the Perilous Realm]]'' (2008 edition), "[[Farmer Giles of Ham]]" The white oxen of [[Rhûn]] were likened by Tolkien to an ''[[wikipedia:Aurochs|aurochs]]'',[[Wayne G. Hammond]], [[Christina Scull]], ''[[The Lord of the Rings: A Reader's Companion]]'', page 265 a bovine species common in the ancient and medieval world until its extinction. ==Etymology== An "elvish" word for "bull" is ''[[mundo]]''.{{L|342}} The [[Sundocarme|Root]] MBUD, which lists among its derivatives a [[Quenya]] word ''mundo'' meaning "snout, nose, cape",{{LR|Etymologies}}, root MBUD could perhaps be related to ''mundo''. In [[Qenya]], the word for "ox" is ''[[yakko]]'' or ''yako'', "cow" is ''[[yaksi]]'' or ''yakse''. In [[Noldorin|Gnomish]], "milch cow" is ''[[gach]]'', "cow" is ''[[gacha]]'', and "a yoke ox - bullock" is ''gagron''. Other Gnomish names are ''mûs'' or ''mui'' ("cow"); ''muir'' ("heifer"); ''[[mû]]'' ("ox"), ''muin'' ("kine, cattle"); and ''[[mugli]]'' ("calf").{{PE|12}}, p. 105{{PE|11}}, pp. 36, 58 In Tolkien's juvenile language [[Nevbosh]], the word for cow is ''woc'', which is both the reverse of ''cow'', and an alteration of the French word ''vache''.[http://www.uib.no/people/hnohf/nevbosh.htm Nevbosh article] in [[Ardalambion]] ==Portrayal in adaptations== '''[[2001]]: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring]]'':''' :A cow can be seen being milked by a Hobbit. Another Hobbit is also seen ploughing a field with a plough pulled by two oxen.[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (extended edition)|''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' (extended edition)]], "[[Concerning Hobbits (scene)|Concerning Hobbits]]" '''[[2012]]: ''[[The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey]]'':''' :[[Bilbo Baggins]] passes by a cow while he jumps over a fence, during his hurried running from Bag End through Hobbiton, to catch up with [[Gandalf]] and the dwarves of Thorin's company.''[[The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey]]'', [[The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey (extended edition)|''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey'' (extended edition)]] ==See also== *[[Kine of Araw]] *[[White cow]] {{References}} [[Category:Animals]]
